name: A. Primes or Palindromes
statement:
Rikhail Mubinchik believes that the current definition of prime numbers
is obsolete as they are too complex and unpredictable. A palindromic
number is another matter. It is aesthetically pleasing, and it has a
number of remarkable properties. Help Rikhail to convince the scientific
community in this!Let us remind you that a number is called if it is
integer larger than one, and is not divisible by any positive integer
other than itself and one.Rikhail calls a number a if it is integer,
positive, and its decimal representation without leading zeros is a
palindrome, i.e. reads the same from left to right and right to left.One
problem with prime numbers is that there are too many of them. Let’s
introduce the following notation: the number of primes no larger than ,
the number of palindromic numbers no larger than . Rikhail wants to
prove that there are a lot more primes than palindromic ones.He asked
you to solve the following problem: for a given value of the coefficient
find the maximum , such that .
editorial:
It is known that amount of prime numbers non greater than is about . We
can also found the amount of palindrome numbers with fixed length it is
about which is . Therefore the number of primes asymptotically bigger
than the number of palindromic numbers and for every constant there is
an answer. Moreover, for this answer the next condition hold: . In our
case . For all numbers smaller than we can check if they are primes (via
sieve of Eratosthenes) and/or palindromes (via trivial algorithm or
compute reverse number via dynamic approach). Then we can calculate
prefix sums ( and ) and find the answer using linear search. For answer
is smaller than . Complexity .
